Session-1.Scene: Mrs. Figg, the Dursleys' usual babysitter for Harry, has broken her leg and can no longer take care of him. The Dursleys consider leaving Harry at home alone, taking him to the zoo and leaving him in the car, or calling Aunt Marge, who hates Harry. Dudley's friend Piers and his mother arrive, and the group goes to the zoo, with Uncle Vernon warning Harry not to cause any trouble or he'll be locked in the cupboard until Christmas.

Dialogue.Dialogue: You could just leave me here,
I won’t blow up the house,

Session-2.Scene: Harry and his family visit the reptile house at the zoo, where Harry strikes up a conversation with a boa constrictor from Brazil. Dudley and Piers interrupt, causing Harry to fall and the glass front of the snake's tank to disappear. The snake slithers out, causing chaos and panic. Harry is blamed for talking to the snake and causing the incident.

Dialogue.Dialogue: I know, Where do you come from, anyway? Was it nice there? Oh, I see — so you’ve never been to Brazil?

Session-3.Scene: In this scene, Harry Potter asks his Aunt Petunia about a wet piece of clothing in a bowl. She reveals that it is his new school uniform, which she is dyeing gray to match the other students' uniforms. Aunt Petunia is irritated by Harry's questions and snaps at him.

Dialogue.Dialogue: What’s this?
Oh, I didn’t realize it had to be so wet.

Session-4.Scene: In this scene, Harry is asked by Uncle Vernon to get the mail, but Dudley is instructed to make Harry get it. Harry finds a letter addressed to him, which is a surprise since no one has ever written to him before. The letter is written on heavy parchment, and the address is written in emerald-green ink. Uncle Vernon takes the letter from Harry and is shocked by its contents. Harry and Dudley are thrown out of the kitchen, and Harry listens at the door to try and hear what is going on.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Make Dudley get it.
That’s mine!
I want to read it, as it’s mine.
I WANT MY LETTER!

Session-5.Scene: Harry wakes up and realizes that his encounter with Hagrid and the news of being a wizard was not a dream. Aunt Petunia knocks on the door, but Harry is too happy to care. An owl delivers a newspaper and demands payment, which Hagrid instructs Harry to give. Hagrid tells Harry that they need to go to Gringotts, the wizard bank, to get money for his school supplies. Hagrid also mentions that he has important business with Dumbledore.

Dialogue.Dialogue: It was a dream, I dreamed a giant called Hagrid came to tell me I was going to a school for wizards. When I open my eyes I’ll be at home in my cupboard. And there’s Aunt Petunia knocking on the door, All right, I’m getting up. Don’t do that.
What? What?
Knuts?
Um — Hagrid?
I haven’t got any money — and you heard Uncle Vernon last night . . . he won’t pay for me to go and learn magic. But if their house was destroyed —
Wizards have banks?
Goblins? Goblins? Goblins? Goblins? Goblins? Goblins? Goblins? Goblins? Goblins? Goblins?

Session-6.Scene: Harry and Hagrid leave the island by boat and Hagrid reveals that he flew there. He asks Harry not to mention it at Hogwarts. Hagrid explains that Gringotts is heavily guarded with spells and enchantments, including dragons. He also mentions the Ministry of Magic, whose main job is to keep the existence of witches and wizards hidden from Muggles.

Dialogue.Dialogue: How did you get here?
Flew?
Why would you be mad to try and rob Gringotts?
There’s a Ministry of Magic?
But what does a Ministry of Magic do?
Why? Why? Why?

Session-7.Scene: Harry and Hagrid went to Flourish and Blotts to buy Harry's school books. Harry was fascinated by the variety of books, including one on curses that he wanted to use on Dudley. Hagrid reminded Harry that he couldn't use magic in the Muggle world. They also visited the Apothecary to buy potion ingredients, and Hagrid promised to buy Harry an owl as a birthday present.

Dialogue.Dialogue: I was trying to find out how to curse Dudley.
You don’t have to —

Session-8.Scene: In this scene, Harry and Hagrid visit Ollivanders, the only place for wands. Mr. Ollivander, the owner, greets them and measures Harry for his wand. He tries several wands before finding the perfect match, which happens to have a phoenix feather core, just like the wand that gave Harry his scar. Mr. Ollivander tells Harry that the wand chooses the wizard and expects great things from him.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Hello,
Oh,

Session-9.Scene: In this scene, Harry expresses his doubts about his magical abilities and why people think he is special. Hagrid reassures him that he will learn everything he needs to know at Hogwarts and advises him to be himself. Hagrid also gives Harry his ticket for Hogwarts and tells him to contact him if he has any problems with the Dursleys.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Everyone thinks I’m special, All those people in the Leaky Cauldron, Professor Quirrell, Mr. Ollivander .. . but I don’t know anything about magic at all. How can they expect great things?I’m famous and I can’t even remember what I’m famous for. I don’t know what happened when Vol-, sorry — I mean, the night my parents died.

Session-10.Scene: In this scene, Harry, Hermione, and their classmates are in a Potions class with Snape. Snape asks Harry a question about the difference between monkshood and wolfsbane, but Harry doesn't know the answer. Hermione tries to answer, but Snape tells her to sit down. Snape then proceeds to teach the class about various potions ingredients and takes points away from Gryffindor. Later in the class, Neville accidentally melts Seamus's cauldron, causing their potion to spill and burn holes in people's shoes. Snape blames Neville and takes points away from Gryffindor again.

Dialogue.Dialogue: I don’t know, sir,
I don’t know, sir,

Session-11.Scene: Harry is taken by Professor McGonagall to meet Oliver Wood, the captain of Gryffindor Quidditch team. Professor McGonagall tells Wood that Harry is a natural at flying and suggests he be the new Seeker for the team. Wood is thrilled and excitedly talks about getting Harry a good broom. Professor McGonagall reminds Harry to train hard and mentions that his father was an excellent Quidditch player.

Session-12.Scene: Harry, Ron, Hermione, and Neville are trying to escape from the trophy room when they encounter Peeves. Peeves threatens to tell Filch about them wandering around at midnight, but Ron tries to take a swipe at him, which turns out to be a mistake.

Dialogue.Dialogue: I think we’ve lost him
I -- told - you. I -- told - you.
Let's go. Shut up, Peeves -- please -- you'll get us thrown out.
Get out of the way,

Session-13.Scene: In this scene, Harry and Hermione are searching for the location of the Sorcerer's Stone. They encounter Peeves, the poltergeist, who refuses to tell them where to go unless Harry says please. After Harry reluctantly says the magic word, Peeves still refuses to give them any information and disappears. Harry and Hermione then realize that they are near the forbidden corridor and try to sneak past Filch, the caretaker, who is searching for them.

Session-14.Scene: Oliver Wood teaches Harry the rules of Quidditch, the sport played on broomsticks at Hogwarts. The game involves seven players on each side, with three Chasers who try to score goals with the Quaffle, one Keeper who guards the goalposts, and two Beaters who protect their side from the Bludgers and try to knock them toward the other team. The Seeker's job is to catch the Golden Snitch, which is worth 150 points and ends the game when caught.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Three Chasers,
The Chasers throw the Quaffle and put it through the hoops to score, So — that’s sort of like basketball on broomsticks with six hoops, isn’t it?
Never mind,
Three Chasers, one Keeper, And they play with the Quaffle.
Three Chasers try and score with the Quaffle; the Keeper guards the goalposts; the Beaters keep the Bludgers away from their team,
Er — have the Bludgers ever killed anyone?

Session-15.Scene: In this scene, Harry, Ron, and Hermione are exchanging Christmas presents. Ron receives a maroon sweater from his mother, while Hermione gives Harry a box of Chocolate Frogs. Harry's last present is an Invisibility Cloak, which Ron identifies as a rare and valuable item. Harry tries it on and Ron confirms that it is indeed an Invisibility Cloak.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Merry Christmas,
You, too, Will you look at this? I’ve got some presents!
What did you expect, turnips?
That’s friendly, Hagrid and my aunt and uncle — so who sent these? That’s really nice of her,
If that’s what I think it is — they’re really rare, and really valuable.
What is it?
It is! Look down!

Session-16.Scene: Harry and Ron use the Invisibility Cloak to sneak into the restricted section of the Hogwarts library and find the Mirror of Erised. Harry sees his deceased parents in the mirror and Ron sees himself as Head Boy, holding the House Cup and Quidditch Cup. They speculate if the mirror shows the future, but their discussion is interrupted by the arrival of Mrs. Norris, Filch's cat. They quickly leave, realizing the danger of being caught.

Dialogue.Dialogue: It’s here — just here — yes! See?
I can’t see anything.
Look! Look at them all . . . there are loads of them. . . .
I can only see you.
Look in it properly, go on, stand where I am.
Look at me!
Can you see all your family standing around you?
No — I’m alone — but I’m different — I look older — and I’m Head Boy!
What?
I am — I’m wearing the badge like Bill used to — and I’m holding the House Cup and the Quidditch Cup — I’m Quidditch captain, too! Do you think this mirror shows the future?
How can it? All my family are dead — let me have another look —
You had it to yourself all last night, give me a bit more time.
You’re only holding the Quidditch Cup, what’s interesting about that? I want to see my parents.
Don’t push me —
Quick!
This isn’t safe — she might have gone for Filch, I bet she heard us. Come on.

Session-17.Scene: Ron asks Harry if he wants to play chess, but Harry declines. Ron suggests they visit Hagrid, but Harry also declines. Ron warns Harry not to go back to the mirror of Erised that night, as he has a bad feeling about it and fears Harry could be caught by Filch, Snape, or Mrs. Norris. Harry is reminded of Hermione by Ron's cautionary words.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Want to play chess, Harry?
No.
Why don’t we go down and visit Hagrid?
No . . . you go . . .
I know what you’re thinking about, Harry, that mirror. Don’t go back tonight.
Why not?
Filch, Snape, and Mrs. Norris are wandering around.  So what if they can’t see you?What if they walk into you?
You sound like Hermione.
I’m serious, Harry, don’t go.

Session-18.Scene: Harry, Hermione, Ron, and Neville are caught by Professor McGonagall after being out of bed and in the Astronomy Tower at one o'clock in the morning. Professor McGonagall accuses them of feeding Draco Malfoy a story about a dragon to get him into trouble and is disgusted with them. All four students receive detentions, and Gryffindor loses fifty points each. Harry is particularly upset because this means they will lose the lead he won in the last Quidditch match.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Fifty?
Professor — please — You can’t —

Session-19.Scene: Harry tells Ron and Hermione that Snape wants the Philosopher's Stone for Voldemort, who is waiting in the forest. He also mentions that Bane, a centaur, was angry with Firenze for saving him and interfering with the planets' predictions. Harry fears that once Snape steals the Stone, Voldemort will come and kill him. Hermione tries to reassure him by saying that Dumbledore is the only one Voldemort is afraid of, and that centaur predictions are not always accurate.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Snape wants the Stone for Voldemort . . . and Voldemort’s waiting in the forest . . . and all this time we thought Snape just wanted to get rich. . . .
Stop saying the name!

Firenze saved me, but he shouldn’t have done so. . . . Bane was furious . . . he was talking about interfering with what the planets say is going to happen. . . . They must show that Voldemort’s coming back. . . . Bane thinks Firenze should have let Voldemort kill me. . . . I suppose that’s written in the stars as well.
Will you stop saying the name!
Professor McGonagall says

Session-20.Scene: Harry, Ron, and Hermione are discussing the strange coincidence that Hagrid, who has always wanted a dragon, suddenly has an egg in his possession after a stranger came to visit. Harry realizes that it's odd for someone to have a dragon egg since it's against wizard law. They decide to go see Hagrid to investigate the situation further. Harry sprints towards the forest without explaining his thoughts to Ron and Hermione.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Where’re you going?
We’ve got to go and see Hagrid, now.
Why?
What are you talking about?

Session-21.Scene: Harry, Ron, and Hermione ask Hagrid about the stranger he played cards with the night he won Norbert. Hagrid tells them that the stranger wouldn't take his cloak off and that he might have been a dragon dealer. Hagrid also mentions that he talked about Hogwarts and his job as a gamekeeper, and the stranger offered to play cards for the dragon egg he had. Harry asks if the stranger seemed interested in Fluffy, and Hagrid confirms that he was.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Yes, please,
No, we’re in a hurry. Hagrid, I’ve got to ask you something. You know that night you won Norbert? What did the stranger you were playing cards with look like?
What did you talk to him about, Hagrid? Did you mention Hogwarts at all?
And did he — did he seem interested in Fluffy?

Session-22.Scene: In this scene, Harry and Ron encounter Peeves the poltergeist, who mistakes the Bloody Baron for being invisible. Harry warns Peeves to stay away from the place as he has some business there. Peeves agrees and leaves, and Ron compliments Harry on his cleverness.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Oh, let's kick her, just this once.
Brilliant, Harry.

Session-23.Scene: In Book 2, Chapter 1 of Harry Potter, Uncle Vernon is angry with Harry for his owl's constant hooting. Harry tries to explain that the owl is bored and needs to fly outside, but Uncle Vernon refuses to listen and threatens to get rid of the owl. Uncle Vernon is convinced that something bad will happen if the owl is let out.

Dialogue.Dialogue: She’s bored,She’s used to flying around outside. If I could just let her out at night —

Session-24.Scene: In this scene, Uncle Vernon is going over the plan for a dinner with the Masons. Aunt Petunia and Dudley have their roles assigned, while Harry is instructed to stay in his room and not make any noise. They plan to impress the Masons and hopefully close a deal. Harry finds Dudley's suggestion for a compliment amusing, causing Aunt Petunia to cry and hug her son. Uncle Vernon leaves to pick up dinner jackets, warning Harry to stay out of Aunt Petunia's way while she cleans.

Dialogue.Dialogue: I’ll be in my bedroom, making no noise and pretending I’m not there,
I’ll be in my room, making no noise and pretending I’m not there,
I’ll be in my room, making no noise and pretending I’m not there,

Session-25.Scene: In this scene, Harry runs into the kitchen and finds Aunt Petunia's pudding floating near the ceiling. Dobby, the house-elf, appears and demands that Harry say he won't return to Hogwarts. Harry refuses, and Dobby insists he must do it for Harry's own good.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Quick! In the closet!
See what it’s like here?See why I’ve got to go back to Hogwarts? It’s the only place I’ve got — well, I think I’ve got friends.
Have you been stopping my letters?

Session-26.Scene: In this scene, Harry receives a letter from the Ministry of Magic for performing magic outside school. Uncle Vernon becomes furious and threatens to lock Harry up and prevent him from going back to Hogwarts. He warns Harry that if he tries to use magic to escape, he will be expelled.

Session-27.Scene: In this scene from chapter 3 of Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets, Harry is greeted by Mrs. Weasley, who invites him in for breakfast. Harry is hesitant, but Ron encourages him to follow her inside.

Session-28.Scene: Mr. Weasley, Fred, George, and Harry are sitting around the table discussing the events of the night. Mr. Weasley had been on duty and had experienced nine raids. He had found a few enchanted items, but nothing too serious. They discuss the idea of Muggle-baiting and how it is difficult to convict anyone for it. Mrs. Weasley then enters the room and confronts Mr. Weasley about the enchanted car that his sons had flown to Harry's house the previous night.

Session-29.Scene: Ron and Harry sneak away from Mrs. Weasley's anger and go up to Ron's bedroom. While climbing the stairs, they pass Ginny, who quickly closes her door. Ron comments on how unusual it is for Ginny to be so quiet since she is usually talkative.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Ginny, You don’t know how weird it is for her to be this shy. She never shuts up normally —

Session-30.Scene: Harry is lost in Knockturn Alley when Hagrid appears and rescues him. Hagrid was looking for a Flesh-Eating Slug Repellent and warns Harry that it's a dodgy place and he shouldn't be seen there. Hagrid brushes off Harry's soot and they head to Gringotts Bank. Harry explains to Hagrid about Dobby and the Dursleys, and Hagrid expresses his anger towards the Dursleys.

Dialogue.Dialogue: I’m staying with the Weasleys but we got separated, I’ve got to go and find them. . . .

Session-31.Scene: In Book 2, Chapter 4 of Harry Potter, Harry and Hagrid meet Hermione at the top of the steps to Gringotts. Hermione notices that Harry's glasses are missing and greets them both warmly. Harry tells Hermione that he is waiting for the Weasleys before going into Gringotts, but Hagrid assures him that they won't have to wait long.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Harry! Harry! Over here! What happened to your glasses? Hello, Hagrid — Oh, it’s wonderful to see you two again — Are you coming into Gringotts, Harry?
As soon as I’ve found the Weasleys,

Session-32.Scene: In this scene, Hagrid, Mrs. Weasley, and Mr. Weasley find Harry in Knockturn Alley and are relieved to see him. Mrs. Weasley cleans Harry off with a clothes brush while Mr. Weasley fixes his glasses with his wand. Hagrid is thanked for finding Harry and says goodbye before leaving for Hogwarts.

Session-33.Scene: In this scene, Gilderoy Lockhart, a famous wizard, spots Harry Potter and Ron Weasley in a bookstore and pulls them to the front of a crowd of excited fans. Lockhart announces that he will be the new Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, much to the delight of the crowd. Harry is uncomfortable with all the attention and tries to escape, but Lockhart keeps him close for the cameras.

Session-34.Scene: In this scene, Ron expresses relief that they no longer have to worry about being caught by the Ministry of Magic while flying in their enchanted car. However, Harry is still anxious about the consequences of their actions and the possibility of being expelled from Hogwarts.

Dialogue.Dialogue: All we’ve got to worry about now are airplanes,

Session-35.Scene: Ron, Harry, and Ron's flying car are still searching for Hogwarts, hours after leaving London. They spot the Hogwarts Express below them, winding past a snowcapped mountain. Ron tries to speed up the car, but the engine begins to whine, causing Harry and Ron to exchange nervous glances. Ron suggests that the car is just tired from the long journey.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Ready for another check on the train? It’s probably just tired, It’s never been this far before. . . .

Session-36.Scene: Ron, Harry, and the flying Ford Anglia are attacked by a violent tree. The tree bends almost double and its gnarled boughs pummel every inch of the car. Ron and Harry try to escape, but the tree is relentless. The car's engine restarts, and they reverse out of reach just in time. Ron is relieved and praises the car for its performance.

Dialogue.Dialogue: What’s happen — ?
We’re done for!
Reverse!
That, was close. Well done, car —

Session-37.Scene: In Book 2, Chapter 5 of Harry Potter, Ron and Harry arrive at Hogwarts and notice that the Sorting ceremony has already begun. They quietly approach the Great Hall and watch as new students are sorted into their respective houses.

Dialogue.Dialogue: I think the feast’s already started, Hey — Harry — come and look — it’s the Sorting!

Session-38.Scene: Harry and Ron notice an empty chair at the staff table and wonder where Snape is. They speculate that he might be ill, have left, or been sacked. However, Snape suddenly appears behind them and asks why they didn't arrive on the school train.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Hang on . . . There’s an empty chair at the staff table. . . . Where’s Snape?
Maybe he’s ill!

Session-39.Scene: Harry and Ron enter Snape's office, which is filled with jars of disgusting things. Snape confronts them about flying the car to Hogwarts and shows them an article in the Evening Prophet about Muggles seeing the car. Snape threatens to expel them and leaves to fetch the people who have the power to do so.

Dialogue.Dialogue: No, sir, it was the barrier at King’s Cross, it —
That tree did more damage to us than we —

Session-40.Scene: Ron and Harry explain to Professor McGonagall that they were unable to board the Hogwarts Express due to the barrier at the station not letting them through. When asked why they didn't send a letter by owl, Harry is at a loss for words and Professor McGonagall scolds him for not thinking of it.

Dialogue.Dialogue: — so we had no choice, Professor, we couldn’t get on the train.
I — I didn’t think —

Session-41.Scene: Harry and Ron are summoned to Dumbledore's office after flying a bewitched car to Hogwarts. Dumbledore calmly listens to their explanation, warning them of the seriousness of their actions and that he will be writing to their families. Snape tries to interject, but Dumbledore defers to Professor McGonagall, who decides to give them detention instead of taking away points from Gryffindor. After McGonagall leaves, Ron and Harry are relieved and enjoy some sandwiches before heading to their dormitory.

Dialogue.Dialogue: We’ll go and get our stuff,
you’re expelling us, aren’t you?
Not much, Professor, I wanted to watch my sister being Sorted —
Oh, good,
Professor, when we took the car, term hadn’t started, so — so Gryffindor shouldn’t really have points taken from it — should it?
I thought we’d had it,
So did I,
Why couldn’t we get through the barrier?
We’ll have to watch our step from now on, though, Wish we could’ve gone up to the feast. . . .
She didn’t want us showing off, Doesn’t want people to think it’s clever, arriving by flying car.

Session-42.Scene: In Book 2, Chapter 6 of Harry Potter, Ron is upset and snaps at someone who suggests that he deserved something. The exact cause of Ron's frustration is not clear from this brief exchange.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Well, I don’t know what you expected, Ron, but you —
Don’t tell me I deserved it,

Session-43.Scene: Lockhart scolds Harry for flying a car to Hogwarts and accuses him of seeking publicity. He tells Harry that he understands how he feels but warns him against trying to get noticed by flying cars. Lockhart boasts about his own fame and tells Harry that he was once a nobody like him. He acknowledges Harry's fame due to his encounter with Voldemort but claims that it's just a start.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Oh, no, Professor, see —

Session-44.Scene: Lockhart scolds Harry for flying a car to Hogwarts and accuses him of seeking publicity. He tells Harry that he understands how he feels but warns him against trying to get noticed by flying cars. Lockhart boasts about his own fame and tells Harry that he was once a nobody like him. He acknowledges Harry's fame due to his encounter with Voldemort but claims that it's just a start.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Stupid — useless — thing —

Session-45.Scene: Lockhart scolds Harry for flying a car to Hogwarts and accuses him of seeking publicity. He tells Harry that he understands how he feels but warns him against trying to get noticed by flying cars. Lockhart boasts about his own fame and tells Harry that he was once a nobody like him. He acknowledges Harry's fame due to his encounter with Voldemort but claims that it's just a start.

Session-46.Scene: In this scene, Lockhart advises Harry not to hand out signed pictures as it may seem bigheaded. Lockhart also mentions that Harry may need to keep a stack of signed pictures handy in the future, but he is not at that stage yet. They then arrive at Lockhart's classroom, and Harry heads to the back of the class and piles all of Lockhart's books in front of him to avoid looking at him.

Session-47.Scene: In this scene, Harry is woken up by Wood for an early Quidditch practice. Despite the crack of dawn and the thin mist outside, Wood is enthusiastic about their new training program and wants to be the first team to start training. Harry reluctantly gets out of bed and prepares to meet Wood on the field in fifteen minutes.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Whassamatter? Oliver, It’s the crack of dawn.

Session-48.Scene: In this scene, Colin Creevey shows Harry a photograph of himself being dragged by Lockhart. Harry refuses to sign it and tries to leave for Quidditch practice, but Colin follows him and bombards him with questions about Quidditch. Harry explains the rules of the game to Colin as they make their way to the field, but eventually manages to shake him off and head to the changing rooms.

Dialogue.Dialogue: No, Sorry, Colin, I’m in a hurry — Quidditch practice —
It’ll be really boring,
Yes, They’re called Bludgers. There are two Beaters on each team who carry clubs to beat the Bludgers away from their side. Fred and George Weasley are the Gryffindor Beaters.

Well, the Quaffle — that’s the biggish red one — is the one that scores goals. Three Chasers on each team throw the Quaffle to each other and try and get it through the goalposts at the end of the pitch — they’re three long poles with hoops on the end.

— is the Golden Snitch, and it’s very small, very fast, and difficult to catch. But that’s what the Seeker’s got to do, because a game of Quidditch doesn’t end until the Snitch has been caught. And whichever team’s Seeker gets the Snitch earns his team an extra hundred and fifty points.
Yes, And there’s the Keeper, too. He guards the goalposts. That’s it, really.

Session-49.Scene: Harry, Ron, and Hermione hide behind a bush to avoid being seen by Lockhart, who is talking to Hagrid. Lockhart offers to help Hagrid and gives him a copy of his book. After Lockhart leaves, the trio goes to Hagrid's house and knocks on his door. Hagrid is happy to see them and invites them in, mistaking them for Lockhart.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Quick, behind here,

Session-50.Scene: In this scene, Professor McGonagall assigns Ron and Harry to different tasks as punishment. Ron is to polish the silver in the trophy room with Filch, without using magic. Harry is to help Professor Lockhart answer his fan mail. Harry tries to get out of it, but McGonagall insists that Lockhart requested him specifically and they must both be there at eight o'clock sharp.

Dialogue.Dialogue: What’re we doing, Professor?
Oh n — Professor, can’t I go and do the trophy room, too?

Session-51.Scene: In this scene, Harry hears a mysterious voice that no one else seems to hear. When he tries to tell Lockhart about it, Lockhart brushes it off and suggests that Harry might be getting drowsy. Lockhart is surprised that they have been talking for almost four hours.

Dialogue.Dialogue: What? That — that voice that said — didn’t you hear it?

Session-52.Scene: Harry encounters Mrs. Norris, the cat used by Argus Filch to catch rule-breakers. Nearly escaping, Harry is caught by Filch who is in a bad mood due to the flu and a recent incident with frog brains on the ceiling. Filch is angry at the mud on the floor from Harry's Quidditch robes and demands Harry to follow him.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Right,

Session-53.Scene: Harry encounters Mrs. Norris, the cat used by Argus Filch to catch rule-breakers. Nearly escaping, Harry is caught by Filch who is in a bad mood due to the flu and a recent incident with frog brains on the ceiling. Filch is angry at the mud on the floor from Harry's Quidditch robes and demands Harry to follow him.

Session-54.Scene: In this scene, Harry is confronted by Filch, who suspects him of reading his private files. Harry denies it, but Filch becomes increasingly agitated, with his eyes bulging and his cheeks twitching. Eventually, he tells Harry to leave and not to tell anyone about the encounter. Filch then mentions that he needs to write up a report on Peeves.

Dialogue.Dialogue: No,

Session-55.Scene: Harry, Ron, and Hermione take a break from the Yule Ball to explore the Hogwarts castle. While walking around, they encounter various ghosts, including the Fat Friar and the Bloody Baron. However, Hermione becomes frightened when they come across Moaning Myrtle, a ghost who haunts a girls' bathroom and causes it to flood with her tantrums.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Shall we have a look around?
Careful not to walk through anyone
Who?
She haunts one of the toilets in the girls’ bathroom on the first floor
She haunts a toilet?

Yes. It’s been out of order all year because she keeps having tantrums and flooding the place. I never went in there anyway if I could avoid it; it’s awful trying to have a pee with her wailing at you —

Session-56.Scene: In this scene, Harry, Ron, and Hermione come across a message on the wall and notice something hanging underneath it. As they approach, they realize that it is Mrs. Norris, the caretaker's cat, hanging by her tail and stiff as a board. They are startled and quickly decide to leave the area.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Pudding might not be finished yet,

Session-57.Scene: In this scene, Harry, Ron, and Hermione come across a message on the wall and notice something hanging underneath it. As they approach, they realize that it is Mrs. Norris, the caretaker's cat, hanging by her tail and stiff as a board. They are startled and quickly decide to leave the area.

Dialogue.Dialogue: What’s that thing — hanging underneath? Let’s get out of here.

Session-58.Scene: Hermione has been affected by the recent attack and has been spending all her time reading. Harry and Ron find out that Hermione has already completed a significant amount of her homework and is trying to read the entire library before Christmas. Justin Finch-Fletchley runs away from Harry when he sees him, and Ron expresses his dislike for him and his admiration for Lockhart.

Dialogue.Dialogue: I don’t believe it, I’m still eight inches short. . . . And Hermione’s done four feet seven inches and her writing’s tiny.
Where is she?
Somewhere over there, Looking for another book. I think she’s trying to read the whole library before Christmas. All that junk about Lockhart being so great —

Session-59.Scene: In this scene, Lockhart assigns homework to the class to write a poem about his defeat of the Wagga Wagga Werewolf. Hermione approaches Lockhart's desk to ask for permission to borrow a book from the Restricted Section of the library, and Lockhart is pleased to help her, using an enormous peacock quill to sign for it.

Dialogue.Dialogue: But the thing is, it’s in the Restricted Section of the library, so I need a teacher to sign for it — I’m sure it would help me understand what you say in Gadding with Ghouls about slow-acting venoms —
Oh, yes, So clever, the way you trapped that last one with the tea-strainer —

Session-60.Scene: Hermione defends Professor Lockhart's intelligence to Harry and Ron as they hurry to the library. She argues that his compliment to Harry for being the best student of the year does not make him a brainless git.

Dialogue.Dialogue: He is not a brainless git,
Just because he said you were the best student of the year —

Session-61.Scene: In this scene, Harry is being pressured by his teammates to win the upcoming Quidditch match against Slytherin. Fred jokes with Harry about the pressure he is under to catch the Snitch before Malfoy does, emphasizing the importance of winning the game.

Session-62.Scene: During a Quidditch match, Harry falls from his broomstick and breaks his arm. Lockhart, the Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher, attempts to fix it with a spell, but instead removes all of the bones from Harry's arm. Despite Harry's protests, Lockhart insists that he be taken to the hospital wing and sends Ron and Hermione to escort him.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Oh, no, not you,
I don’t want a photo of this, Colin, Why can’t I just go to the hospital wing?
No — don’t —

Session-63.Scene: After Harry's Quidditch match, Madam Pomfrey gives him Skele-Gro to regrow his bones, warning him of the unpleasant side effects. Ron and Hermione congratulate Harry on his victory, but Hermione is still suspicious of how Malfoy fixed the Bludger. They plan to ask him when they use the Polyjuice Potion, but Ron jokes that he wouldn't want to drink a potion with bits of Slytherins in it.

Dialogue.Dialogue: We can add that to the list of questions we’ll ask him when we’ve taken the Polyjuice Potion,
I hope it tastes better than this stuff. . . .
If it’s got bits of Slytherins in it? You’ve got to be joking,

Session-64.Scene: Harry meets Ron and Hermione in the bathroom where they have been brewing the Polyjuice Potion. Hermione tells Harry that they already know about Colin's attack and that they need to get a confession out of Malfoy as soon as possible. Harry then tells them about Dobby's visit and what he had said about the Chamber of Secrets being opened before. Hermione is shocked by this revelation.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Fine,
We’d’ve come to meet you, but we decided to get started on the Polyjuice Potion,
We’ve decided this is the safest place to hide it.
We already know — we heard Professor McGonagall telling Professor Flitwick this morning. That’s why we decided we’d better get going — The Chamber of Secrets has been opened before?

Session-65.Scene: In this scene, Malfoy conjures a snake that threatens to attack Justin Finch-Fletchley. Lockhart's attempt to remove the snake only makes it angrier, and it slithers towards Justin. Harry, without thinking, tells the snake to leave Justin alone, and it becomes docile. Justin, however, is angry and storms out of the hall. Snape looks at Harry in a calculating way, and there is ominous muttering from the crowd. Ron pulls Harry away from the scene.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Leave him alone!
Come on,

Session-66.Scene: Ron and Hermione take Harry to the Gryffindor common room and confront him about being a Parselmouth, someone who can speak to snakes. Harry is confused and doesn't understand why it's a big deal, but Ron and Hermione explain that it's a rare and often associated with Salazar Slytherin, the founder of Slytherin House. They worry that people will think Harry is related to Slytherin and that it will cause problems.

Dialogue.Dialogue: You’re a Parselmouth. Why didn’t you tell us?
I’m a what?
A boa constrictor told you it had never seen Brazil?
What’s wrong with everyone? Listen, if I hadn’t told that snake not to attack Justin —
Oh, that’s what you said to it?

What d’you mean? You were there — you heard me — I spoke a different language? But — I didn’t realize — how can I speak a language without knowing I can speak it? D’you want to tell me what’s wrong with stopping a massive snake biting off Justin’s head? What does it matter how I did it as long as Justin doesn’t have to join the Headless Hunt? But I’m not,
You’ll find that hard to prove, He lived about a thousand years ago; for all we know, you could be.

Session-67.Scene: Harry and Ron are discussing the state of Harry's robes, which have all their pockets hanging out. Ron suggests that someone has been looking for something, and Harry realizes that Riddle's diary is missing.

Dialogue.Dialogue: No idea, Riddle’s diary’s gone,
What?

Session-68.Scene: Ron and Harry are walking in the dark forest when they hear something big moving and breaking branches. Ron panics and Harry tells him to be quiet. They wait in terror as the noise gets closer, and then there is a strange rumbling noise followed by silence. They wonder if the creature has gone.

Dialogue.Dialogue: What?
There’s something moving over there, Listen . . . sounds like something big. . . .
Oh, no, Oh, no, oh, no, oh —
Shut up, It’ll hear you. What d’you think it’s doing?
Probably getting ready to pounce,
D’you think it’s gone?
Dunno —

Session-69.Scene: In this scene, Harry wakes Ron up in the middle of the night to discuss the death of a girl found in a bathroom. Harry suggests that the girl may still be in the bathroom, and Ron realizes that Harry is referring to Moaning Myrtle, a ghost who haunts the girls' bathroom.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Ron,
You don’t think — not Moaning Myrtle?

Session-70.Scene: Lockhart is packing up to leave Hogwarts after being exposed as a fraud by Ron and Harry. He tries to justify his actions by saying that his books wouldn't have sold well if people didn't think he had done all those things. Harry is incredulous that Lockhart had been taking credit for what a load of other people had done and Lockhart tries to explain that there was work involved. He then packs his bags and says there is only one thing left.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Are you going somewhere?
What about my sister?
You wrote them!
So you’ve just been taking credit for what a load of other people have done?

Session-71.Scene: Ron calls the Dursleys' home looking for Harry, but Uncle Vernon answers the phone and becomes angry when he hears Ron's voice. He denies knowing Harry and tells Ron never to contact him again. Uncle Vernon then becomes furious with Harry for giving out their phone number.

Dialogue.Dialogue: HELLO? HELLO? CAN YOU HEAR ME? I — WANT — TO — TALK — TO — HARRY — POTTER!

Session-72.Scene: In this scene, Professor McGonagall questions why the class did not applaud her transformation and Hermione explains that they were reading tea leaves in their first Divination class. Professor McGonagall then reveals that Sybill Trelawney has predicted the death of one student each year, but none have died yet. She expresses her lack of patience for Divination and warns Harry that he still has homework to do, despite his predicted death.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Please, Professor, we’ve just had our first Divination class, and we were reading the tea leaves, and —
Me,

Session-73.Scene: In this scene, Ron is worried about a black dog he saw and believes it to be a Grim, which is an omen of death. Hermione dismisses his concerns, stating that Grims are not omens but the cause of death. Ron and Hermione argue about Divination and Arithmancy classes, with Hermione getting angry and storming off.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Ron, cheer up, You heard what Professor McGonagall said.
Harry, you haven’t seen a great black dog anywhere, have you?
Yeah, I have, I saw one the night I left the Dursleys’.
Probably a stray,
Hermione, if Harry’s seen a Grim, that’s — that’s bad, My — my uncle Bilius saw one and — and he died twenty-four hours later!
Coincidence,
You don’t know what you’re talking about! Grims scare the living daylights out of most wizards!
There you are, then, They see the Grim and die of fright.
There was nothing woolly about the Grim in that cup! Professor Trelawney said you didn’t have the right aura! You just don’t like being bad at something for a change!

If being good at Divination means I have to pretend to see death omens in a lump of tea leaves, I’m not sure I’ll be studying it much longer! That lesson was absolute rubbish compared with my Arithmancy class!
What’s she talking about? She hasn’t been to an Arithmancy class yet.

Session-74.Scene: Hermione expresses her concern about Hagrid's well-being after his class was disrupted by Malfoy. Harry reassures her that Madam Pomfrey can easily heal any injuries. Ron is worried about the incident happening during Hagrid's first class. He blames Malfoy for causing trouble.

Dialogue.Dialogue: D’you think he’ll be all right?
’Course he will. Madam Pomfrey can mend cuts in about a second,
That was a really bad thing to happen in Hagrid’s first class, though, wasn’t it? Trust Malfoy to mess things up for him. . . .

Session-75.Scene: In this scene, Ron and Harry are angry with Hermione for not lying to Snape about Neville's mistake in the potion class, which resulted in Gryffindor losing five points. Hermione disappears for a moment and then reappears, out of breath and with a split bag full of heavy books. Ron questions her about the books, and Hermione seems vague about why she's carrying them. Ron and Harry suspect that she's hiding something from them.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Five points from Gryffindor because the potion was all right! Why didn’t you lie, Hermione? You should’ve said Neville did it all by himself! Where is she? She was right behind us,
There she is,
How did you do that?
What? What?
One minute you were right behind us, the next moment, you were back at the bottom of the stairs again.
What? What? Oh — I had to go back for something. Oh no —
Why are you carrying all these around with you?
You know how many subjects I’m taking, Couldn’t hold these for me, could you?
But — You haven’t got any of these subjects today. It’s only Defense Against the Dark Arts this afternoon.
Oh yes, I hope there’s something good for lunch, I’m starving,
D’you get the feeling Hermione’s not telling us something?

Session-76.Scene: In the greenhouse, Ron is angry and upset about his pet rat Scabbers, who is hiding and shaking in his bed. Lavender Brown is crying because her pet rabbit Binky has been killed by a fox. Hermione tries to console Lavender but ends up questioning why she was dreading Binky's death. Ron and Hermione argue, and Harry is nervous about asking Professor McGonagall for permission to go to Hogsmeade. McGonagall ultimately denies Harry's request because his aunt and uncle did not sign his permission form.

Dialogue.Dialogue: How’s Scabbers?
He’s hiding at the bottom of my bed, shaking,
What’s the matter, Lavender?
Oh, I’m sorry, Lavender.
Er —
You — you were dreading Binky being killed by a fox?
Oh, Was Binky an old rabbit?
But then, why would you dread him dying? Well, and she can’t have been dreading it, because it’s come as a real shock —
Ask her now,
Oh,
Go for it, Harry,
er er
But — Professor, my aunt and uncle — you know, they’re Muggles, they don’t really understand about — about Hogwarts forms and stuff, If you said I could go —

Session-77.Scene: Hermione and Ron try to cheer up Harry, who is disappointed about not being able to go to Hogsmeade. Harry tells them not to worry about him and sees them off to the entrance hall. Malfoy taunts Harry about staying behind and being scared of the dementors. Filch is checking names and faces to ensure no one is sneaking out.

Dialogue.Dialogue: We’ll bring you lots of sweets back from Honeydukes,
Yeah,
Don’t worry about me, I’ll see you at the feast. Have a good time.

Session-78.Scene: Harry, feeling restless, wanders the corridors of Hogwarts and runs into Professor Lupin. Lupin asks Harry where Ron and Hermione are, and Harry tells him they're in Hogsmeade. Lupin invites Harry into his office to show him a grindylow for their next lesson.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Hogsmeade,

Session-79.Scene: In chapter 8 of book 3, Harry, Ron, and Hermione enjoy a delicious feast at Hogwarts. Harry notices Snape's eyes flickering towards Professor Lupin more often than usual. The feast ends with an entertaining performance by the Hogwarts ghosts. Despite Malfoy's attempt to spoil the evening, Harry remains in a good mood.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Yeah, maybe,

Session-80.Scene: In chapter 9 of book 3, Harry is preoccupied with the upcoming Quidditch match and receives tips from Oliver Wood. However, he is late for Defense Against the Dark Arts class after Wood talks to him for too long. As he rushes off, Wood warns him about Cedric Diggory's fast swerve.

Session-81.Scene: In this scene, Wood expresses concern about the possibility of dementors appearing at the next Quidditch match and potentially affecting Harry's performance. Harry reassures him that he is being trained to ward off the dementors. Wood also learns that Harry's Firebolt broomstick has been confiscated and is being checked for jinxes, possibly sent by Sirius Black. Wood promises to talk to Professor McGonagall to try and get the broomstick cleared for use in the upcoming match against Ravenclaw.

Dialogue.Dialogue: I’m working on it, Professor Lupin said he’d train me to ward off the dementors. We should be starting this week.He said he’d have time after Christmas.
No,
He got a Firebolt for Christmas,
Don’t get excited, Oliver, I haven’t got it anymore. It was confiscated.
Sirius Black, He’s supposed to be after me. So McGonagall reckons he might have sent it.

Session-82.Scene: Harry attempts to sneak into Hogsmeade by using the Dissendium spell to open the secret passageway, but Neville interrupts him. Harry lies to Neville about his plans and convinces him to go to the library with him. Snape appears and questions their presence, but Harry manages to convince him that they are not up to anything suspicious. Snape remains suspicious of Harry and tells them to return to Gryffindor Tower.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Dissendium!
What are you up to?
Er — not now — I was going to go to the library and do that vampire essay for Lupin —
Er — hang on — yeah, I forgot, I finished it last night!
We’re not — meeting here, We just — met here.

Session-83.Scene: In chapter 14 of book 3, Ron and Harry visit the post office and Zonko's joke shop. Ron pretends to be checking the price of an owl to allow Harry to look around the post office unnoticed. At Zonko's, they purchase various joke items, including Dungbombs, Hiccup Sweets, Frog Spawn Soap, and Nose-Biting Teacups.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Where are you? Are you still there? This feels weird. . . .

Session-84.Scene: Hermione is stressed and busy preparing for exams, but also worried about Buckbeak's appeal, which is set for the same day as their last exam. Harry receives a note from Hagrid informing them that the appeal will be attended by someone from the Ministry of Magic and an executioner. Draco seems pleased that Buckbeak will be killed and Harry struggles to control his anger towards him. The students are busy with their exams, and Hermione is fussing over her tortoise transformation task.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Er — are you sure you’ve copied down these times right?
What? Yes, of course I have.
Is there any point asking how you’re going to sit for two exams at once?
No, Have either of you seen my copy of Numerology and Grammatica?
Oh, yeah, I borrowed it for a bit of bedtime reading,
It’s from Hagrid, Buckbeak’s appeal — it’s set for the sixth.
That’s the day we finish our exams,
And they’re coming up here to do it, Someone from the Ministry of Magic and — and an executioner.
They’re bringing the executioner to the appeal! But that sounds as though they’ve already decided!
Yeah, it does,
They can’t! I’ve spent ages reading up on stuff for him; they can’t just ignore it all!
Mine still had a spout for a tail, what a nightmare. . . .
Were the tortoises supposed to breathe steam?
It still had a willow-patterned shell, d’you think that’ll count against me?

Session-85.Scene: Mrs. Weasley wakes up Harry and Ron in the early morning. Harry puts on his glasses and sees Fred and George at the foot of his bed, who are still half asleep.

Session-86.Scene: Harry is lying in his bunk, imagining himself flying like Krum and performing the Wronski Feint. Suddenly, Mr. Weasley wakes him up, shouting that something urgent has happened. Harry can hear screams and people running outside. Mr. Weasley tells him to grab a jacket and get outside quickly.

Dialogue.Dialogue: ’S’ matter?

Session-87.Scene: Hermione, Ron, and Harry have just finished their Divination homework and are discussing their predictions. Hermione then shows them a box of badges with the letters S.P.E.W on them, which stands for the Society for the Promotion of Elfish Welfare. Hermione explains that she wants to secure fair wages and working conditions for house-elves and change the law about non-wand use. Ron and Harry are hesitant to join, but Hermione is determined to recruit members and start a leaflet campaign.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Hello, I’ve just finished!
So have I!
Not going to have a very good month, are you?
Ah well,
You seem to be drowning twice,
Oh am I? I’d better change one of them to getting trampled by a rampaging hippogriff.
Don’t you think it’s a bit obvious you’ve made these up?
How dare you! We’ve been working like house-elves here! It’s just an expression, What’s in the box?
Funny you should ask,
What’s this about? What’s this about?
Not spew, It’s S-P-E-W. Stands for the Society for the Promotion of Elfish Welfare.
Never heard of it,
Well, of course you haven’t, I’ve only just started it.
Yeah? How many members have you got?
Well — if you two join — three,
‘Spew’?

S-P-E-W! I was going to put Stop the Outrageous Abuse of Our Fellow Magical Creatures and Campaign for a Change in Their Legal Status — but it wouldn’t fit. So that’s the heading of our manifesto. I’ve been researching it thoroughly in the library. Elf enslavement goes back centuries. I can’t believe no one’s done anything about it before now.

Our short-term aims, are to secure house-elves fair wages and working conditions. Our long-term aims include changing the law about non-wand use, and trying to get an elf into the Department for the Regulation and Control of Magical Creatures, because they’re shockingly underrepresented.
And how do we do all this?

We start by recruiting members, I thought two Sickles to join — that buys a badge — and the proceeds can fund our leaflet campaign. You’re treasurer, Ron — I’ve got you a collecting tin upstairs — and Harry, you’re secretary, so you might want to write down everything I’m saying now, as a record of our first meeting.

Session-88.Scene: Harry, Ron, and Hermione hear a strange noise coming from the lake and witness a ship rising from the water. The ship is carrying a group of people, all of whom are wearing shaggy, matted fur cloaks. The man leading them is Professor Karkaroff, who greets Dumbledore and introduces his student, Viktor Krum, to him. Harry recognizes Krum from the Triwizard Tournament.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Can you hear something?
It’s a mast!
Harry

Session-89.Scene: In this scene, Hermione and Ron argue over the cold weather and the lack of cloaks. Viktor Krum and the Durmstrang students sit at the Slytherin table, causing Malfoy and his friends to look smug. Ron makes sarcastic comments about Malfoy's behavior towards Krum, and suggests offering Krum a space in their dormitory. The Durmstrang students seem impressed with the Hogwarts dining hall, while Filch adds four chairs to the staff table, even though there are only two extra people. Ron is still staring at Krum.

Dialogue.Dialogue: It’s not that cold, Why didn’t they bring cloaks?
Over here! Come and sit over here! Over here! Hermione, budge up, make a space —
What?

Too late, Yeah, that’s right, smarm up to him, Malfoy, I bet Krum can see right through him, though . . . bet he gets people fawning over him all the time. . . . Where d’you reckon they’re going to sleep? We could offer him a space in our dormitory, Harry . . . I wouldn’t mind giving him my bed, I could kip on a camp bed.
They look a lot happier than the Beauxbatons lot, But there are only two extra people, Why’s Filch putting out four chairs, who else is coming?
Eh?

Session-90.Scene: Dumbledore welcomes the foreign students to Hogwarts and invites them to enjoy the feast. The house-elves have prepared a variety of dishes, including foreign ones like Bouillabaisse. The Durmstrang students wear deep blood-red robes, and Hagrid arrives late with a heavily bandaged hand. Ron makes a sarcastic comment about the Skrewts liking Hagrid's fingers as food.

Dialogue.Dialogue: No one’s making you stay!
What?
Bouillabaisse,
Bless you,
It’s French, I had it on holiday summer before last. It’s very nice.
I’ll take your word for it,
Skrewts doing all right, Hagrid?
Yeah, I’ll just bet they are, Looks like they’ve finally found a food they like, doesn’t it? Hagrid’s fingers.

Session-91.Scene: During the Triwizard Tournament feast, Ron becomes infatuated with a girl from Beauxbatons who serves him bouillabaisse. The girl has silvery-blonde hair, deep blue eyes, and very white teeth. Ron is convinced she is a veela, a magical creature known for their beauty and charm. Hermione dismisses Ron's claims and points out the arrival of Ludo Bagman and Mr. Crouch, who organized the tournament.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Yeah, have it,
Yeah, Yeah, it was excellent. She’s a veela!
Of course she isn’t! I don’t see anyone else gaping at her like an idiot!
I’m telling you, that’s not a normal girl! They don’t make them like that at Hogwarts!
They make them okay at Hogwarts,
When you’ve both put your eyes back in, you’ll be able to see who’s just arrived.
What?
They organized the Triwizard Tournament, didn’t they? I suppose they wanted to be here to see it start.

Session-92.Scene: In chapter 17 of Book 4, Harry denies putting his name in the Goblet of Fire, but both Dumbledore and Professor McGonagall don't believe him. Dumbledore calls Harry to the top table, and he walks up, feeling the stares of everyone in the Great Hall. Dumbledore tells him to go through the door, but he doesn't seem pleased.

Dialogue.Dialogue: I didn’t put my name in, You know I didn’t.

Session-93.Scene: Harry enters the Gryffindor common room to find Ron lying on the bed, grinning in a strange way. Ron congratulates Harry for getting past the Age Line and into the Triwizard Tournament, but Harry denies putting his name in the Goblet of Fire. Ron doesn't believe him and accuses him of lying. Harry gets angry and tells Ron to go to bed.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Where’ve you been?
Oh hello, So, Congratulations.
What d’you mean, congratulations?
No, Not even Fred and George. What did you use — the Invisibility Cloak?
The Invisibility Cloak wouldn’t have got me over that line,
Oh right, I thought you might’ve told me if it was the Cloak . . . because it would’ve covered both of us, wouldn’t it? But you found another way, did you?
Listen, I didn’t put my name in that goblet. Someone else must’ve done it.
What would they do that for?
I dunno, To kill me.

If you don’t want everyone else to know, fine, but I don’t know why you’re bothering to lie, you didn’t get into trouble for it, did you? That friend of the Fat Lady’s, that Violet, she’s already told us all Dumbledore’s letting you enter. A thousand Galleons prize money, eh? And you don’t have to do end-of-year tests either. . . .
I didn’t put my name in that goblet!
Yeah, okay, Only you said this morning you’d have done it last night, and no one would’ve seen you. . . . I’m not stupid, you know.
You’re doing a really good impression of it,
Don’t you? You want to get to bed, Harry. I expect you’ll need to be up early tomorrow for a photo-call or something.

Session-94.Scene: Malfoy taunts Harry about the Triwizard Tournament, but is distracted when Hagrid introduces the class to the Blast-Ended Skrewts. Hagrid pulls Harry aside and expresses his concern about Harry's participation in the tournament, but believes Harry's claim of innocence. The skrewts prove to be difficult to control and cause chaos among the class. Hagrid expresses his worry about Harry's tendency to attract trouble.

Dialogue.Dialogue: One of the champions,
You believe I didn’t do it, then?
Wish I knew who did do it,

Session-95.Scene: Harry and Hermione are discussing the upcoming first task of the Triwizard Tournament when they are interrupted by the arrival of Rita Skeeter and her photographer. Harry hides from them, and after they leave, he tells Hermione that he thinks Rita Skeeter is staying in the village to watch the first task. Hermione suggests they go to the Three Broomsticks for a butterbeer, but Harry remains silent, causing Hermione to become irritated.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Don’t move your lips so much then.
Come on, please just take off your Cloak for a bit, no one’s going to bother you here.
Oh yeah? Look behind you. She’s staying in the village. I bet she’s coming to watch the first task.
She’s gone, You don’t have to talk to Ron!

Session-96.Scene: In this scene, Harry is in Moody's office, which is full of odd objects. Moody asks Harry about the dragons and advises him to play to his strengths. Moody suggests that Harry should use a simple spell to get what he needs and encourages him to think about what he is best at. Harry realizes that he is a good flier and Moody suggests that he should use a spell to get a broom.

Dialogue.Dialogue: What?
And what’s the mirror for?
I didn’t cheat, It was — a sort of accident that I found out.
No,
I haven’t got any,
Quidditch,
Yeah, but . . . I’m not allowed a broom, I’ve only got my wand —

Session-97.Scene: Harry, Ron, and Hermione discuss the events of the first task of the Triwizard Tournament. Ron suggests that Harry could win the tournament, but Hermione is skeptical and warns that the next tasks could be even more dangerous. They send a letter to Sirius via Pigwidgeon, who struggles to fly with the heavy letter attached to his leg. Ron reminds Harry of his surprise party, and they head downstairs to join the festivities.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Fits, doesn’t it? Remember what Malfoy said on the train, about his dad being friends with Karkaroff? Now we know where they knew each other. They were probably running around in masks together at the World Cup. . . . I’ll tell you one thing, though, Harry, if it was Karkaroff who put your name in the goblet, he’s going to be feeling really stupid now, isn’t he? Didn’t work, did it? You only got a scratch! Come here — I’ll do it — There’s no way any of the other tasks are going to be that dangerous, how could they be? You know what? I reckon you could win this tournament, Harry, I’m serious.
Harry’s got a long way to go before he finishes this tournament, If that was the first task, I hate to think what’s coming next.

Right little ray of sunshine, aren’t you? You and Professor Trelawney should get together sometime. Well, we’d better get downstairs for your surprise party, Harry — Fred and George should have nicked enough food from the kitchens by now.

Session-98.Scene: The Fat Lady is irritated when Ron, Hermione, and Harry leave. Hermione leads them down six floors and into a brightly lit corridor with cheerful paintings of food. Harry realizes that Hermione is trying to get them involved in her spew campaign again. Hermione insists that she only wants to show them something and not to make them stop working.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Oh hang on . . . Wait a minute, Hermione. . . .
What?
I know what this is about,
Hermione! You’re trying to rope us into that spew stuff again!
No, no, I’m not! And it’s not spew, Ron —
Changed the name, have you? I’m not barging into that kitchen and trying to make them stop work, I’m not doing it —
I’m not asking you to! I came down here just now, to talk to them all, and I found — oh come on, Harry, I want to show you!

Session-99.Scene: In this scene, Professor McGonagall informs Harry that he needs to find a dance partner for the Yule Ball as part of his duties as a Hogwarts champion. Harry is reluctant and insists that he doesn't dance, but Professor McGonagall is firm in her expectations of him. Harry is left with no choice but to find a partner.

Dialogue.Dialogue: What partners?
Dance partners? I don’t dance,
I don’t dance,
But — I don’t —

Session-100.Scene: Harry and Ron discuss Harry's difficulty in asking a girl out because they always seem to be in groups. Ron jokingly suggests lassoing one, but Harry is too nervous to even consider it. Ron reassures Harry that he shouldn't have any trouble finding a date, as he is a champion and just defeated a Hungarian Horntail.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Why do they have to move in packs? How’re you supposed to get one on their own to ask them?
Lasso one? Got any idea who you’re going to try? Listen, you’re not going to have any trouble. You’re a champion. You’ve just beaten a Hungarian Horntail. I bet they’ll be queuing up to go with you.

Session-101.Scene: Harry and Ron are leaving Hagrid's hut when Ron suddenly stops and whispers to Harry, asking if he knew that Hagrid is half-giant. Harry admits that he didn't know, but doesn't understand why it matters. Ron insists that he'll explain inside and urges Harry to follow him.

Dialogue.Dialogue: C’mon, Let’s go. . . . What’s up?
Did you know? About Hagrid being half-giant?
So what? So what?
I’ll explain inside, c’mon. . . .

Session-102.Scene: Cedric Diggory approaches Harry and thanks him for telling him about the dragons. He then advises Harry to take a bath with the golden egg and think things over. Cedric tells Harry to use the prefects' bathroom on the fifth floor with the password pine fresh.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Yeah?
Yeah,
What?

Session-103.Scene: Hagrid teaches the class about unicorns and allows them to pat the baby unicorns. Harry is nervous, but Hagrid reassures him that he can do anything he sets his mind to, referencing his success in the Triwizard Tournament. Harry feels the urge to confess that he doesn't know how to survive in the lake, but Hagrid tells him he's going to win and can feel it.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Yeah,
Bit,

Session-104.Scene: In this scene, Hermione reveals that she has subscribed to the Daily Prophet to stay informed. However, when a group of owls deliver letters to her during breakfast, she discovers that they are all hate mail, with one even containing a curse that causes her hands to erupt in boils. Harry and Ron help her to the hospital wing, and Ron warns her that she should have been more careful not to anger Rita Skeeter. Later, as Harry and Ron leave Herbology, they encounter Malfoy and his gang, who taunt Harry about Hermione's distress at breakfast.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Percy won’t’ve had time to answer yet, We only sent Hedwig yesterday.
No, it’s not that, I’ve taken out a subscription to the Daily Prophet. I’m getting sick of finding everything out from the Slytherins.
Good thinking! Hey, Hermione, I think you’re in luck —
It hasn’t got a newspaper, though,
How many subscriptions did you take out?
What on earth — ? Oh really!
What’s up?
It’s — oh how ridiculous — They’re all like it!
Undiluted bubotuber pus!
Ow!
You’d better get up to the hospital wing, We’ll tell Professor Sprout where you’ve gone. . . .
I warned her! Look at this one . . . ’ Blimey, she’d better watch out for herself.

Session-105.Scene: Harry tries to enter Dumbledore's office using the old password, but the gargoyle doesn't move. Snape appears and questions Harry's presence, but Dumbledore arrives and Harry informs him that Mr. Crouch is in the forest and needs to speak with him urgently. Dumbledore asks Harry for more information and hurries to the forest with him. Harry explains that Crouch is acting strangely and mentions Voldemort. Dumbledore asks if anyone else saw Crouch and they encounter the Beauxbatons carriage emerging from the darkness.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Lem — lemon drop! Move! C’mon!
I need to see Professor Dumbledore! It’s Mr. Crouch . . . he’s just turned up . . . he’s in the forest . . . he’s asking —
From the Ministry! He’s ill or something — he’s in the forest, he wants to see Dumbledore! Just give me the password up to —
Dumbledore!
Look,
Professor! Mr. Crouch is here — he’s down in the forest, he wants to speak to you!
He’s not acting normally, He doesn’t seem to know where he is.
No, Krum and I were talking, Mr. Bagman had just finished telling us about the third task, we stayed behind, and then we saw Mr. Crouch coming out of the forest —

Session-106.Scene: In this scene, Harry and Dudley are arguing about Harry's wand. Dudley tries to insult Harry by bringing up his boxing title, but Harry retaliates by mocking Dudley's lack of bravery. However, the conversation takes a dark turn when Dudley reveals that he heard Harry talking in his sleep about Cedric, causing Harry to feel a cold sensation in his stomach. Harry points his wand at Dudley and warns him not to talk about it again.

Dialogue.Dialogue: How long have you been ‘Big D’ then? But you’ll always be Ickle Diddykins to me. You don’t tell her to shut her face. What about ‘popkin’ and ‘Dinky Diddydums,’ can I use them then?
What thing?
Whereas you just need four mates behind you before you can beat up a ten-year-old.
This is night, Diddykins.
I —
Don’t ever talk about that again,

Session-107.Scene: After a sudden return to normality, Harry realizes that he is drenched in sweat and Dudley is lying on the ground whimpering. As he checks on Dudley, Mrs. Figg, their neighbor, arrives and warns Harry not to put his wand away in case there are more Dementors around. She expresses her anger towards Mundungus Fletcher.

Dialogue.Dialogue: THIS WAY! DUDLEY? DUDLEY!

Session-108.Scene: Harry gives Aunt Petunia a Howler, but Uncle Vernon tries to stop her from opening it. When Aunt Petunia opens it, the envelope bursts into flames and a voice echoes from it, saying, Remember my last, Petunia. Aunt Petunia decides to let Harry stay, but only because she doesn't want the neighbors to talk. She orders Harry to stay in his room and not leave the house.

Dialogue.Dialogue: You can open it if you like, but I’ll hear what it says anyway. That’s a Howler. It’ll happen anyway —

Session-109.Scene: Mr. Weasley and Harry rush to the Ministry of Magic for an urgent matter, but they are running late due to a change in the schedule. They take the lift to the Atrium and then go down a secret corridor to reach a courtroom. Mr. Weasley is out of breath and tells Harry to go inside the courtroom alone.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Aren’t — aren’t you coming with — ?

Session-110.Scene: Harry, Ron, and Hermione are walking down a staircase lined with portraits of old witches and wizards. Hermione notices that Harry is angry about something and Ron explains that Seamus thinks Harry is lying about You-Know-Who. Hermione is disappointed that Lavender thinks the same. Hermione reminds Harry and Ron of Dumbledore's speech about the importance of unity and friendship to fight against You-Know-Who's gift for spreading discord and enmity. They enter the Great Hall and Angelina tells Harry that she has been made Gryffindor Quidditch Captain and they need a new Keeper.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Anyway, what’s up, Harry? You look really angry about something.
Seamus reckons Harry’s lying about You-Know-Who,
Yes, Lavender thinks so too,
Been having a nice little chat with her about whether or not I’m a lying, attention-seeking prat, have you?

No, I told her to keep her big fat mouth shut about you, actually. And it would be quite nice if you stopped jumping down Ron’s and my throats, Harry, because if you haven’t noticed, we’re on your side.
Sorry,
That’s quite all right, Don’t you remember what Dumbledore said at the end-of-term feast last year? About You-Know-Who.
How do you remember stuff like that?
I listen, Ron,
So do I, but I still couldn’t tell you exactly what —
The point, is that this sort of thing is exactly what Dumbledore was talking about. You-Know-Who’s only been back two months, and we’ve started fighting among ourselves.
And Harry said it last night, if that means we’re supposed to get matey with the Slytherins, fat chance.
Well, I think it’s a pity we’re not trying for a bit of inter-House unity,
Yeah, we really ought to be trying to make friends with people like that, Dumbledore didn’t even mention how long that Grubbly-Plank woman’s staying,
Maybe . . .
Well . . . maybe he didn’t want to draw attention to Hagrid not being here.
How could we not notice?
Hi, Angelina. Hi,
Nice one,
Okay,
I’d forgotten Wood had left, I suppose that will make quite a difference to the team?
I s’pose, He was a good Keeper . . .
Still, it won’t hurt to have some new blood, will it?

Session-111.Scene: In this scene, Harry, Ron, and Hermione are discussing the recent claims made by a student named Luna Lovegood that she witnessed Cedric Diggory's murder and dueled with Voldemort. Harry is shaken by the news and wonders why everyone believes Luna's story now when Dumbledore had already told them the truth two months ago. Hermione suggests that people may not have believed Dumbledore's story in the first place. The trio decides to leave the conversation.

Dialogue.Dialogue: What I don’t get, is why they all believed the story two months ago when Dumbledore told them . . .
The thing is, Harry, I’m not sure they did, Oh, let’s get out of here.

Session-112.Scene: Harry and Hermione discuss whether people believe that Voldemort has returned. Hermione explains that after Cedric's death, they only had Dumbledore's word for it, and that people had spent the summer reading about Harry being a nutcase and Dumbledore going senile. Harry is frustrated that people don't believe him, but Hermione asks him to stop biting her head off.

Dialogue.Dialogue: What d’you mean, you’re not sure they believed Dumbledore?

Look, you don’t understand what it was like after it happened, You arrived back in the middle of the lawn clutching Cedric’s dead body. . . . None of us saw what happened in the maze. . . . We just had Dumbledore’s word for it that You-Know-Who had come back and killed Cedric and fought you.
Which is the truth!
I know it is, Harry, so will you please stop biting my head off?

Session-113.Scene: Harry is in a hurry to get to dinner before his detention with Umbridge, but is stopped by Angelina Johnson, who is angry with him for getting detention on the same day as Keeper tryouts. Harry explains that he got detention for telling the truth about Voldemort to Umbridge, but Angelina insists that he must find a way to attend the tryouts.

Dialogue.Dialogue: What now?
What? Why . . . oh yeah, Keeper tryouts!
I didn’t decide not to be there! I got detention from that Umbridge woman, just because I told her the truth about You-Know-Who —

Session-114.Scene: In this scene, Umbridge instructs Harry to write lines with a blood quill as punishment for lying about Dumbledore's Army. Harry uses the opportunity to shift his chair to see the Gryffindor Quidditch team practicing outside. As he writes the lines, the cut in his hand caused by the quill reopens and bleeds. Harry tries to watch the Quidditch practice while avoiding being caught by Umbridge. The scene ends with Umbridge checking on Harry's progress.

Session-115.Scene: Harry walks to the Owlery to send a letter to Sirius via Hedwig. He sees a winged horse and is startled. Cho Chang arrives to send a letter to her mother and they discuss Quidditch and Umbridge. Filch enters and accuses Harry of ordering Dungbombs, but Cho defends him. Filch leaves, warning Harry not to order any Dungbombs.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Yeah, ’bye, I’m not doing anything wrong, There you are, Get down here, I’ve got a letter for you. Right, I know this says ‘Snuffles’ on the outside, but it’s for Sirius, okay? Safe flight, then, Hi, Hi,
Nice day,
No,
Yeah, It’s my friend Ron Weasley, d’you know him?
Yeah, I think so. I didn’t see his tryout, though, I was in detention.
Who told you I was ordering Dungbombs?
I can’t, it’s gone. Gone,
Gone, Gone, Gone,
Thanks,
No,

Session-116.Scene: Hermione, Harry, and Ron are walking down the High Street when Hermione stops to buy a new quill from Scrivenshaft’s Quill Shop. Ron is angry about Ginny dating Michael Corner, but Hermione explains that Ginny had given up on Harry months ago. Hermione also mentions Cho's interest in Harry, causing him to feel self-conscious.

Dialogue.Dialogue: They met at the Yule Ball and they got together at the end of last year, Hmm . . . I could do with a new quill.
Which one was Michael Corner?
The dark one,
I didn’t like him,
Big surprise,
But, I thought Ginny fancied Harry!
Ginny used to fancy Harry, but she gave up on him months ago. Not that she doesn’t like you, of course,
So that’s why she talks now? She never used to talk in front of me.
Exactly, Yes, I think I’ll have this one . . .  this is exactly why Ginny hasn’t told you she’s seeing Michael, she knew you’d take it badly. So don’t harp on about it, for heaven’s sake.
What d’you mean, who’s taking anything badly? I’m not going to harp on about anything . . .
And talking about Michael and Ginny . . . what about Cho and you?
What d’you mean?
Well, she just couldn’t keep her eyes off you, could she?

Session-117.Scene: In this scene, Harry, Ron, and Hermione are discussing the recent educational decree that bans all student organizations. They notice that many students are avoiding them, including Cho Chang, who they suspect may be scared off by Umbridge's notice. Angelina then approaches them, revealing that they need to ask permission to re-form the Gryffindor Quidditch team due to the new decree. Ron warns Harry not to lose his temper with Umbridge again, and they head off to their History of Magic class, suspecting that Umbridge may be there.

Dialogue.Dialogue: It’s okay,
What? What?
No way,
Okay, okay, Don’t worry, I’ll behave myself . . .
Bet Umbridge is in History of Magic, She hasn’t inspected Binns yet. . . . Bet you anything she’s there . . .

Session-118.Scene: Ron and Hermione's prefect duties become more demanding as Christmas approaches, including supervising castle decoration, watching over younger students during break times, and patrolling the corridors with Filch. Hermione is worried about running out of elf hats, while Harry is resentful of Hogwarts due to his Quidditch ban and concerns about Hagrid. The D.A. meetings will stop over the holidays, and Hermione is going skiing with her parents, while Ron invites Harry to spend Christmas at the Burrow.

Dialogue.Dialogue: You try putting up tinsel when Peeves has got the other end and is trying to strangle you with it, And they’re cheeky little snotrags, you know, we definitely weren’t that rude when we were in first year, He’s got dung for brains, that one,
All those poor elves I haven’t set free yet, having to stay over during Christmas because there aren’t enough hats!
But you’re coming too! Didn’t I say? Mum wrote and told me to invite you weeks ago!

Session-119.Scene: Harry stays behind in the common room hoping to receive a Merry Christmas from Cho. When they are alone, Cho starts crying and Harry tries to comfort her. She apologizes and mentions Cedric's death, but Harry tells her that he was good at magic and that Voldemort would have killed him anyway. Cho compliments Harry on his teaching skills and they share a moment under the mistletoe where Cho confesses that she really likes him.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Wha — ? What’s up?
He was really good at it, or he could never have got to the middle of that maze. But if Voldemort really wants to kill you, you don’t stand a chance.
Yeah, well, I dunno why, nor does anyone else, so it’s nothing to be proud of.
Thanks,
Yeah, It’s probably full of nargles, though.
No idea, You’d have to ask Loony. Luna, I mean.

Session-120.Scene: Harry and Tonks are sitting together on a train, and Tonks asks Harry if there is any Seer blood in his family. Harry responds negatively, and Tonks muses that what Harry is doing is not really prophecy, but rather seeing the present. She finds it odd but useful.

Dialogue.Dialogue: No,

Session-121.Scene: Harry is on the Hogwarts Express with Ron, Hermione, and Ginny, when he overhears a conversation between Lupin and Tonks about Voldemort's plans to obtain a weapon. Harry realizes that he is the weapon Voldemort is after and becomes paranoid that Voldemort could be inside him, listening to his thoughts. Mrs. Weasley notices that Harry looks unwell and suggests he go to bed for a few hours before dinner.

Dialogue.Dialogue: What’s he after apart from followers?  Stuff he can only get by stealth . . . like a weapon. Something he didn’t have last time.

Session-122.Scene: Harry experiences excruciating pain and loses consciousness, only to wake up to maniacal laughter coming out of his own mouth. He tells Ron that something good has happened to Voldemort, something he has been hoping for. Ron helps Harry up and mentions that Hermione had warned him that his defenses would be low after Snape's intrusion into his mind.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Harry? HARRY! What happened?
I . . . dunno . . . He’s really happy . . . really happy . . .
You-Know-Who is?
Something good’s happened, Something he’s been hoping for.

Hermione told me to come and check on you, She says your defenses will be low at the moment, after Snape’s been fiddling around with your mind. . . . Still, I suppose it’ll help in the long run, won’t it?

Session-123.Scene: In this scene, Dumbledore and Harry are preparing to leave Privet Drive. Dumbledore tells Harry that he can use magic if there is an attack, but he doesn't think there will be one. Dumbledore also mentions that Harry hasn't passed his Apparition Test, but he will take him with him by holding onto his arm tightly. They then apparate away from Privet Drive.

Dialogue.Dialogue: But I thought I’m not allowed to use magic outside school, sir?
Why not, sir?
No, I thought you had to be seventeen?

Session-124.Scene: Dumbledore asks Harry if he has been reading the Daily Prophet and if he knows about the leaks regarding his adventure in the Hall of Prophecy. Harry confirms that he knows, but Dumbledore reassures him that only two people know the full contents of the prophecy and that many have only guessed that it concerns him. Dumbledore suggests that Harry should tell Ron and Hermione about the prophecy, as they are his friends and deserve to know. Harry is hesitant, but Dumbledore encourages him to confide in them.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Yes,
Yes,
No,
I didn’t want —

Session-125.Scene: Harry arrives at the Burrow and is greeted by Mrs. Weasley, who comments on his and Ron's growth. She then prepares onion soup for Harry and they discuss Horace Slughorn, whom Harry has convinced to take the job at Hogwarts. Mrs. Weasley reveals that Slughorn was not fond of Arthur, but Arthur has recently been promoted.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Yeah, I am, So Hermione’s here?
Thanks, Mrs. Weasley.

Session-126.Scene: In this scene, Verity informs Fred and George that a customer is looking for a joke cauldron. George promptly leaves to attend to the customer, while Fred and Harry stay behind. Fred and George refuse to take Harry's payment for the Decoy Detonators, stating that he gave them their start-up loan and he can take whatever he wants for free, as long as he tells people where he got it from.

Dialogue.Dialogue: But —

Session-127.Scene: Harry, Ron, and Hermione are discussing the whereabouts of a young boy they saw in Knockturn Alley. Harry wonders where the boy's mother is, but Ron suggests that he might have given her the slip. Hermione questions why the boy would do that.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Wonder where his mummy is?
Given her the slip by the looks of it,
Why, though?

Session-128.Scene: In this scene, Ron and Harry are discussing their class schedules and confirm that neither of them are taking Care of Magical Creatures. They also mention Hermione and wonder if she is taking the class or not.

Dialogue.Dialogue: You’re not taking Care of Magical Creatures, are you?
And you’re not either, are you? And Hermione, she’s not, is she?
