Session-129.Scene: Hermione reads from the Daily Prophet that Stan Shunpike, the conductor of the Knight Bus, has been arrested on suspicion of being a Death Eater. Harry and Ron are surprised and skeptical, but Hermione is troubled. She mentions that people are becoming scared and some students are being withdrawn from Hogwarts. Hermione also notes that Dumbledore's seat at the staff table has been empty, suggesting that he may have left the school to do something with the Order.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Anyone we know dead?
No, but there have been more dementor attacks, And an arrest.
Excellent, who?
Stan Shunpike,
What? Stan Shunpike, a Death Eater? No way!
He might have been put under the Imperius Curse, You never can tell.

It doesn’t look like it, It says here he was arrested after he was overheard talking about the Death Eaters’ secret plans in a pub. If he was under the Imperius Curse, he’d hardly stand around gossiping about their plans, would he?
It sounds like he was trying to make out he knew more than he did, Isn’t he the one who claimed he was going to become Minister of Magic when he was trying to chat up those veela?
Yeah, that’s him, I dunno what they’re playing at, taking Stan seriously.

They probably want to look as though they’re doing something, People are terrified — you know the Patil twins’ parents want them to go home? And Eloise Midgen has already been withdrawn. Her father picked her up last night.
What! But Hogwarts is safer than their homes, bound to be! We’ve got Aurors, and all those extra protective spells, and we’ve got Dumbledore!

I don’t think we’ve got him all the time, Haven’t you noticed? His seat’s been empty as often as Hagrid’s this past week. I think he’s left the school to do something with the Order, I mean . . . it’s all looking serious, isn’t it?

Session-130.Scene: Ginny points out to Harry that Ron is in the corner of the room with Lavender Brown, and they are embracing each other so tightly that it's hard to tell whose hands are whose. Ginny comments on their behavior, saying that it looks like Ron is eating her face, but she also acknowledges that Ron needs to refine his technique. Ginny then congratulates Harry on his recent Quidditch game.

Session-131.Scene: Harry tells Mr. Weasley about what he overheard between Malfoy and Snape. Lupin and Mr. Weasley suggest that Snape may have been pretending to offer help to Malfoy to find out what he was up to. Lupin defends Snape, saying that he made the Wolfsbane Potion for him every month when he taught at Hogwarts, and that he trusts Dumbledore's judgment in trusting Snape. Harry argues that Dumbledore can make mistakes, but Lupin suggests that Harry's hatred for Snape is inherited from his father and godfather.

Dialogue.Dialogue: No problem, Has it been busy at the Ministry?
They’re not still holding Stan Shunpike, are they?
I won’t say anything, Mr. Weasley, you know what I told you at the station when we were setting off for school?
Yeah, I know, I saw in the Prophet that you’d looked . . . but this is something different. . . . Well, something more . . .  Yeah, I thought you’d say that. But how do we know?
But,
do you honestly like Snape?
But he ‘accidentally’ let it slip that you’re a werewolf, so you had to leave!
Maybe he didn’t dare mess with the potion with Dumbledore watching him!

Session-132.Scene: Dumbledore continues his tale of Tom Riddle, explaining how he was placed in Slytherin House and quickly learned of his ability to speak Parseltongue. Despite his talent and good looks, Riddle showed no signs of arrogance or aggression and drew attention and sympathy from the staff. Dumbledore admits that he did not fully trust Riddle but chose to give him a chance. As Riddle moved up the school, he gathered a group of friends who became the forerunners of the Death Eaters. Dumbledore reveals that Riddle was obsessed with his parentage and eventually discovered the existence of Slytherin's surviving line. He then shows Harry a memory of Riddle's visit to his Gaunt relatives.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Didn’t you tell them, sir, what he’d been like when you met him at the orphanage?
But you didn’t really trust him, sir, did you? He told me .. . the Riddle who came out of that diary said, ‘Dumbledore never seemed to like me as much as the other teachers did. ’

Session-133.Scene: In chapter 18 of book 6, Harry asks Slughorn about Horcruxes. Slughorn becomes terrified and denies knowing anything about them. Harry tries to convince him that there might be more to the memory, but Slughorn becomes angry and leaves.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Sir,I wanted to ask you something.
Sir, I wondered what you know about . . . about Horcruxes?
I asked whether you know anything about Horcruxes, sir.
Yes,

Session-134.Scene: In chapter 19 of Book 6, Harry confronts Malfoy and demands to know where he is going. Malfoy refuses to tell him and mocks Harry's fame as the Chosen Captain and the Boy Who Scored.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Where’re you going?

Session-135.Scene: Hagrid and Harry approach a small crowd gathered at the foot of the Astronomy Tower where Dumbledore's body lies. Harry feels detached from the pain of the hexes that hit him during the previous half hour, but is overwhelmed by the pressing feeling in his chest. He crouches down beside Dumbledore, knowing there was no hope from the moment the Body-Bind Curse was lifted, and sees the greatest wizard he had ever met, spread-eagled and broken.

Session-136.Scene: Harry takes a last look at his childhood home, reminiscing about the good times and showing Hedwig where he used to sleep. Suddenly, there is a deafening roar, and figures start popping into sight as their Disillusionment Charms lift. Hagrid arrives on an enormous motorbike with a black sidecar attached, along with other people dismounting from brooms and skeletal, black winged horses. Harry hurries out to greet them, and they all exchange greetings before setting off.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Don’t you want to take a last look at the place? We’ll never be here again. Don’t you want to remember all the good times? I mean, look at this doormat.  What memories .. . Dudley puked on it after I saved him from the dementors. . . . Turns out he was grateful after all, can you believe it? . . . And last summer, Dumbledore walked through that front door. . . . And under here, Hedwig is where I used to sleep! You never knew me then — Blimey, it’s small, I’d forgotten. . . .

Session-137.Scene: In this scene, Harry has a vision of Voldemort torturing Ollivander for information about why a different wand did not work in place of Lucius's destroyed wand. Harry's scar tingles as he witnesses Voldemort's vicious anger and the frail old man writhing in agony. Ron and Hermione try to convince Harry to stay and not let Voldemort inside his head again. Hermione is terrified that Voldemort is taking over the Ministry and the Wizarding world.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Harry? Harry?
Harry, come back in the house, You aren’t still thinking of leaving?
Yeah,
Are you all right? You look awful!
Well,

But it was supposed to have stopped! Your scar — it wasn’t supposed to do this anymore! You mustn’t let that connection open up again — Dumbledore wanted you to close your mind! Harry, he’s taking over the Ministry and the newspapers and half the Wizarding world! Don’t let him inside your head too!

Session-138.Scene: Fleur suggests disguising Harry for the wedding to prevent any Death Eaters from getting information. Mrs. Weasley asks Ron to clean his room for the wedding, which he protests. Harry offers to help, but Mrs. Weasley assigns him and Hermione other tasks. Mr. Weasley reveals that he has Sirius's bike parts and plans to work on it secretly.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Why? Why does my room have to be cleaned out? Harry and I are fine with it the way it is!
And are they getting married in my bedroom? No! So why in the name of Merlin’s saggy left —
I can help, some of it’s my mess,

Session-139.Scene: In this scene from Chapter 8 of Book 7, Krum points out Ginny's good looks and asks if she is related to Harry. Harry confirms that she is his relative and warns Krum that she is seeing someone who is a jealous and big bloke. Krum expresses his disappointment that all the good-looking girls are taken, questioning the point of being an international Quidditch player.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Yeah, and she’s seeing someone. Jealous type.Big bloke. You wouldn’t want to cross him.

Session-140.Scene: Harry is found by Hermione after disappearing and searching for his mother's letter. They discuss the possibility of someone searching for information on the Order or Dumbledore. Harry wants to go to Godric's Hollow to talk to Bathilda Bagshot, who knew his parents and Dumbledore, but Hermione is scared and thinks they should avoid the place where Harry's parents are buried. They also discuss Muriel's comments about Dumbledore, and Hermione urges Harry not to believe everything he hears from malicious sources. They decide to go to the kitchen for breakfast.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Harry? Harry! Harry!
I’m here! What’s happened?
We woke up and didn’t know where you were! Ron! I’ve found him! RON!
Good! Tell him from me he’s a git!
Harry, don’t just disappear, please, we were terrified! Why did you come up here anyway? What have you been doing?
Look what I’ve just found.
Oh, Harry . . .
And there’s this too. I’ve been looking for the rest of the letter, but it’s not here.
Did you make all this mess, or was some of it done when you got here?
Someone had searched before me,
I thought so. Every room I looked into on the way up had been disturbed. What were they after, do you think?
Information on the Order, if it was Snape.
But you’d think he’d already have all he needed, I mean, he was in the Order, wasn’t he?
Well then, what about information on Dumbledore? The second page of this letter, for instance. You know this Bathilda my mum mentions, you know who she is?
Who?
Bathilda Bagshot, the author of —
A History of Magic, So your parents knew her? She was an incredible magical historian.
And she’s still alive, and she lives in Godric’s Hollow, Ron’s Auntie Muriel was talking about her at the wedding.She knew Dumbledore’s family too. Be pretty interesting to talk to, wouldn’t she?

I understand why you’d love to talk to her about your mum and dad, and Dumbledore too, But that wouldn’t really help us in our search for the Horcruxes, would it? Harry, I know you really want to go to Godric’s Hollow, but I’m scared, I’m scared at how easily those Death Eaters found us yesterday. It just makes me feel more than ever that we ought to avoid the place where your parents are buried, I’m sure they’d be expecting you to visit it.
It’s not just that, Muriel said stuff about Dumbledore at the wedding. I want to know the truth. . . .
Of course, I can see why that’s upset you, Harry —
I’m not upset,

Harry, do you really think you’ll get the truth from a malicious old woman like Muriel, or from Rita Skeeter? How can you believe them? You knew Dumbledore!  Shall we go down to the kitchen? Find something for breakfast?

Session-141.Scene: Harry has a vision of Voldemort murdering a woman and her family. Hermione and Ron burst into the bathroom to find out what happened. Hermione scolds Harry for not using Occlumency to block Voldemort's connection, but Harry insists on using it to gain information about Voldemort's plans. Harry believes that Voldemort is after a foreign wandmaker named Gregorovitch, who may be able to explain what happened with Harry's wand. Hermione questions Harry's reluctance to take responsibility for his own power, but Ron tells her to drop it and focus on their plan to go to the Ministry.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Harry! HARRY! Harry, open up! What
What
You were yelling your head off!
Oh yeah . . . I must’ve dozed off or —
Harry, please don’t insult our intelligence, We know your scar hurt downstairs, and you’re white as a sheet.
Fine. By now he’s probably killed her whole family. And he didn’t need to. It was Cedric all over again, they were just there. . . .
Harry! HARRY! Dumbledore wanted you to use Occlumency! He thought the connection was dangerous — Voldemort can use it, Harry! What good is it to watch him kill and torture, how can it help?
Because it means I know what he’s doing,
So you’re not even going to try to shut him out?
Hermione, I can’t. You know I’m lousy at Occlumency, I never got the hang of it.
You never really tried! I don’t get it, Harry — do you like having this special connection or relationship or what — whatever —
Like it? Would you like it?
I — no — I’m sorry, Harry, I didn’t mean —
I hate it, I hate the fact that he can get inside me, that I have to watch him when he’s most dangerous. But I’m going to use it.
Dumbledore —
Forget Dumbledore. This is my choice, nobody else’s. I want to know why he’s after Gregorovitch.
Who?
He’s a foreign wandmaker, He made Krum’s wand and Krum reckons he’s brilliant.
But according to you, Voldemort’s got Ollivander locked up somewhere. If he’s already got a wandmaker, what does he need another one for?
Harry, you keep talking about what your wand did, but you made it happen! Why are you so determined not to take responsibility for your own power?
Because I know it wasn’t me! And so does Voldemort, Hermione! We both know what really happened!
Drop it, It’s up to him. And if we’re going to the Ministry tomorrow, don’t you reckon we should go over the plan?

Session-142.Scene: Hermione and Harry decide to move to a more sheltered location as Hermione is feeling uneasy due to the possibility of someone being outside. Hermione suggests using the Invisibility Cloak to Disapparate to their new location. Harry looks at the Sneakoscope on the table and wonders if Hermione's fears are justified. However, Hermione thinks that the snow in the dark can play tricks on one's eyes.

Dialogue.Dialogue: We’ll go somewhere more sheltered, I kept thinking I could hear people moving outside. I even thought I saw somebody once or twice. I’m sure I imagined it, The snow in the dark, it plays tricks on your eyes. . . . But perhaps we ought to Disapparate under the Invisibility Cloak, just in case?

Session-143.Scene: Hermione, Ron, and Harry discuss Xenophilius Lovegood's hypocrisy and the danger of being associated with Harry. Harry gazes out the window towards the Burrow, thinking of Ginny. Xenophilius shows them his invention, the Wrackspurt siphons, and offers them Gurdyroots tea. Harry asks Xenophilius about the symbol he was wearing at Bill and Fleur's wedding, and Xenophilius confirms it is the sign of the Deathly Hallows.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Well, it’s about that symbol you were wearing around your neck at Bill and Fleur’s wedding, Mr. Lovegood. We wondered what it meant.

Session-144.Scene: Harry, Ron, and Hermione discuss the three Deathly Hallows and which one they would choose. Hermione believes that the story of the Hallows is just a morality tale, but Ron argues that Harry's Invisibility Cloak is infallible and perfect. Harry is distracted by a painting of his own face on the ceiling of the room above and begins to climb the stairs to investigate.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Probably to show the Poisoning Department at St. Mungo’s,
What do you think?
Oh, Harry, it’s a pile of utter rubbish. This can’t be what the sign really means. This must just be his weird take on it. What a waste of time.
I s’pose this is the man who brought us Crumple-Horned Snorkacks,
You don’t believe it either?

Nah, that story’s just one of those things you tell kids to teach them lessons, isn’t it? ‘Don’t go looking for trouble, don’t pick fights, don’t go messing around with stuff that’s best left alone! Just keep your head down, mind your own business, and you’ll be okay. ’ Come to think of it, maybe that story’s why elder wands are supposed to be unlucky.
What are you talking about?
One of those superstitions, isn’t it? ‘May-born witches will marry Muggles. ’ ‘Jinx by twilight, undone by midnight. ’ ‘Wand of elder, never prosper. ’ You must’ve heard them. My mum’s full of them.

Harry and I were raised by Muggles, We were taught different superstitions. I think you’re right, It’s just a morality tale, it’s obvious which gift is best, which one you’d choose — the Cloak, the Cloak, the Cloak, the Cloak, the Cloak, the Cloak, the Cloak, the Cloak, the Cloak, the Cloak,
the wand, the wand,
the stone.
You’re supposed to say the Cloak, but you wouldn’t need to be invisible if you had the wand. An unbeatable wand, Hermione, come on!
We’ve already got an Invisibility Cloak,
And it’s helped us rather a lot, in case you hadn’t noticed!

Only if you shouted about it, Only if you were prat enough to go dancing around, waving it over your head, and singing, ‘I’ve got an unbeatable wand, come and have a go if you think you’re hard enough. ’ As long as you kept your trap shut —
Yes, but could you keep your trap shut? You know, the only true thing he said to us was that there have been stories about extra-powerful wands for hundreds of years.
There have?

The Deathstick, the Wand of Destiny, they crop up under different names through the centuries, usually in the possession of some Dark wizard who’s boasting about them. Professor Binns mentioned some of them, but — oh, it’s all nonsense. Wands are only as powerful as the wizards who use them. Some wizards just like to boast that theirs are bigger and better than other people’s.
But how do you know, that those wands — the Deathstick and the Wand of Destiny — aren’t the same wand, surfacing over the centuries under different names?
What, and they’re all really the Elder Wand, made by Death? So why would you take the stone?

Well, if you could bring people back, we could have Sirius . . . Mad-Eye . . . Dumbledore . . . my parents. . . . But according to Beedle the Bard, they wouldn’t want to come back, would they? I don’t suppose there have been loads of other stories about a stone that can raise the dead, have there?

No, I don’t think anyone except Mr. Lovegood could kid themselves that’s possible. Beedle probably took the idea from the Sorcerer’s Stone; you know, instead of a stone to make you immortal, a stone to reverse death.

What about the Cloak, though? Don’t you realize, he’s right? I’ve got so used to Harry’s Cloak and how good it is, I never stopped to think. I’ve never heard of one like Harry’s. It’s infallible. We’ve never been spotted under it —
Of course not — we’re invisible when we’re under it, Ron!

But all the stuff he said about other cloaks, and they’re not exactly ten a Knut, you know, is true! It’s never occurred to me before, but I’ve heard stuff about charms wearing off cloaks when they get old, or them being ripped apart by spells so they’ve got holes in. Harry’s was owned by his dad, so it’s not exactly new, is it, but it’s just . . . perfect!
Yes, all right, but Ron, the stone . . . Harry, what are you doing? I don’t think you should look around when he’s not here!

Session-145.Scene: In this scene, Hermione criticizes Harry for his lack of interest in locating more Horcruxes, and Harry becomes convinced that Dumbledore left the Resurrection Stone hidden in the golden Snitch. Hermione quotes a line from the Bible, and Harry quotes a line from the prophecy, but they fail to understand each other's point of view. Harry gives up on Hermione's understanding.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Obsession? We’re not the ones with an obsession, Harry! We’re the ones trying to do what Dumbledore wanted us to do! I thought it was You-Know-Who we were supposed to be fighting?

Session-146.Scene: Harry spends time at Bill and Fleur's cottage, feeling scared and full of doubts about his decision not to race Voldemort to the wand. Ron and Hermione argue about whether Dumbledore is really dead or not, with Ron pointing out evidence that suggests he might not be. Harry is unsure about Dumbledore's intentions and feels angry that he did not explain things before he died. The scene ends with someone calling Harry's name from behind them.

Dialogue.Dialogue: What if Dumbledore wanted us to work out the symbol in time to get the wand? What if working out what the symbol meant made you ‘worthy’ to get the Hallows? Harry, if that really is the Elder Wand, how the hell are we supposed to finish off You-Know-Who?
You could never have done that, Harry, You couldn’t have broken into Dumbledore’s grave.
But is he dead? Look at the facts, Hermione, The silver doe.
Harry admits he could have imagined the eye! Don’t you, Harry?
I could have,
But you don’t think you did, do you?
No, I don’t,
There you go! If it wasn’t Dumbledore, explain how Dobby knew we were in the cellar, Hermione? I dunno, it could’ve been his ghost!
Dumbledore wouldn’t come back as a ghost, He would have gone on.
What d’you mean, ‘gone on’?

Session-147.Scene: Aberforth, Harry, Ron, and Hermione discuss how to get out of Hogsmeade without being caught. Aberforth advises them to wait until daybreak and then leave on foot, but Harry insists that they need to get into Hogwarts. Aberforth warns Harry to forget about Dumbledore's plans and to save himself, but Harry insists that he has a job to do. Aberforth questions whether Dumbledore was honest with Harry and implies that he was not.

Dialogue.Dialogue: We’re not leaving, We need to get into Hogwarts.
We’ve got to,
You don’t understand. There isn’t much time. We’ve got to get into the castle. Dumbledore — I mean, your brother — wanted us —
You don’t understand.
I didn’t mean that, It’s . . . he left me a job.
I-it’s not easy, no,
I can’t.
But you’re fighting too, you’re in the Order of the Phoenix —
I can’t leave,
I can’t. It’s got to be me, Dumbledore explained it all —

Session-148.Scene: Harry, Ron, and Hermione are under attack by Death Eaters and giant spiders. They try to move Fred's body, but Percy refuses to leave his brother's side until they finally convince him to go. They run into the corridor and see many people running back and forth, and Percy goes after Rookwood. Hermione tries to stop Ron from running after Percy and reminds him that they need to find and kill the snake to end the war. She urges Harry to find Voldemort and locate the snake.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Get down! Percy, come on, we’ve got to move!
Percy! Percy, you can’t do anything for him! We’re going to —
It brought friends! Let’s move, NOW! Here,
Harry, in here! Listen to me — LISTEN, RON!
I wanna help — I wanna kill Death Eaters —

Ron, we’re the only ones who can end it! Please — Ron — we need the snake, we’ve got to kill the snake! We will fight! We’ll have to, to reach the snake! But let’s not lose sight now of what we’re supposed to be d-doing! We’re the only ones who can end it! You need to find out where Voldemort is, because he’ll have the snake with him, won’t he? Do it, Harry — look inside him!

Session-149.Scene: In this scene, Harry and Dumbledore discuss the fact that Voldemort has the Elder Wand. Dumbledore suggests that if Harry chooses to return, there is a chance that Voldemort may be defeated for good. Harry is hesitant but ultimately decides to return. Before leaving, Harry asks if his conversation with Dumbledore is real or just in his head. Dumbledore confirms that it is happening inside his head but that doesn't mean it's not real.

Dialogue.Dialogue: Voldemort’s got the Elder Wand.
But you want me to go back?
Tell me one last thing, Is this real? Or has this been happening inside my head?
